args: Put this article into one of the following categories. Use the most specific category that makes sense. If you are unsure, respond Other. The allowed categories are: Abortion, AI, Associated Press, Birthright citizenship, CFPB, Climate, Crypto, D.C., Debt ceiling, DEI in schools, DEI in the federal government, Department of Education, Deportations, DOGE, End birthright citizenship, Eric Adams case, Expanding executive power, Federal funding, Federal grant pause, Federal office space, Federal worker buyout, Federal workers return to office, Federal workforce reductions, FEMA, Firing government watchdogs, Food safety, Foreign aid, Foreign policy, Gaza, Government shutdown, Guantánamo Bay, Health agencies' communications pause, Health care, Immigration policy, Interest rates, Iran, Islamic State, Israel, Jan. 6, Kennedy Center, NIH, NYC congestion toll, Other, Panama Canal, Pardons, Reclassifying federal jobs, Sanctions, Senior government officials ousted, Taiwan, Targeting political enemies, Targeting protesters, Tariffs, The media, TikTok ban, Transgender policy, U.S.-Mexico border, USAID, USPS, War in Ukraine, World Health Organization Respond ONLY with the category. Musk throws cold water on funding for Trump AI initiative Elon Musk, the Tesla CEO and top ally of President Donald Trump, is casting doubt on the funding source for a massive artificial intelligence project that Trump announced Tuesday. “They don’t actually have the money,” Musk said late Tuesday on X, responding to an announcement about the initiative from OpenAI, one of the partners in the venture. The project, deemed “Stargate,” seeks to spend as much as $500 billion over the next four years to build up to 20 new data centers to support AI projects. Trump announced it at the White House alongside OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Oracle Chairman Larry Ellison and SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son. In a follow-up X post, Musk made clear that he was referring to SoftBank, a Japanese technology company with whom Trump has previously touted other deals. Musk and Altman have long feuded over OpenAI, an artificial intelligence research organization. They were co-chairs of OpenAI when it launched in 2015, but Musk departed years later and sued the company last year, accusing it of straying from its founding mission. Musk was one of the largest donors to Trump’s 2024 campaign effort and is now leading a government efficiency commission in the new administration.
